75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (20:30): hali, do you know how I may put the null in the bottom?
08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:36): I have the following SQL statement: select doc_id from t_document where CONTAINS(doc_front, '(wind)', 7.1) > 0 OR CONTAINS(doc_body, '(wind)', 7.2) > 0);
08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:36): when i use autotrace to see the plan, i see that the indexes are not being used
08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:37): if i remove the or and look in only one text it uses the index: select doc_id from t_document where CONTAINS(doc_body, '(wind)', 7.1) > 0;
802104471a04f63cfc497bc9446e9bf3 (20:47): you could always do a union
75273e2d05e97198fa881ed7690ca760 (20:47): nikozu: I think may be you use function
08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:48): mackwork: how would the first statement be re-written using union?
802104471a04f63cfc497bc9446e9bf3 (20:48): do a statement with the first CONTAINS
802104471a04f63cfc497bc9446e9bf3 (20:49): then UNION it with an identical statement, except with the second CONTAINS clause you want
08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:49): mackwork: gotcha... let me try that. thanks
802104471a04f63cfc497bc9446e9bf3 (20:50): it is probably a hackish solution, i'm not an oracle whiz by a long shot
08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:50): mackwork: wow, that actually worked, i think... it's using the indexes anyways :P
802104471a04f63cfc497bc9446e9bf3 (20:51): basically the rule of thumb is that if you have a slow OR, try a UNION

08165bdc79a8b342eb0401243249d5da (20:52): yeah, the only thing is, that sql i pasted in is a super simplified version of what i'm actually using... i'm not sure if using union will work or not in this case
802104471a04f63cfc497bc9446e9bf3 (20:53): that guy is really freaky looking though
